Award.AbstractNarration:
The Center for Sustainable Materials Chemistry will focus on fundamental aspects of the aqueous chemistry of inorganic nanoclusters and their transformation to solids. It will explore new approaches to synthesizing inorganic clusters and how to tune their reactivity by coupling theory with experiment. It will prepare from the clusters dense and porous thin solid films with minimum energy input and unprecedented control, emphasizing the so-called green elements in the periodic table. The chemical transformations leading to these high-quality films will be investigated with various techniques offering near-atomic resolution capabilities. By applying the film chemistry to lamination, the center will study and tune reactions -neutralization, metathesis, interdiffusion, and redox - providing insights on basic chemistry processes involving these materials. By pushing the film chemistry to ultra-thin limits (< 1 nm), the center will open new opportunities to synthesize targeted compositions and structures Beyond the Molecular Frontier. This research holds promise of transforming current technologies to produce high performance materials at dimensions < 10 nm with potential broad applications from electronic device fabrication to optical coatings and use in energy storage materials and applications using environmentally benign methods.

The center is committed to education at all levels. Graduate students and postdoctoral associates will have access to professional development opportunities in entrepreneurship, teaching, immersion courses, and public communication. A pilot effort to a high school with a diverse population will promote learning through a graduate-student-in-residence program. It will develop a web-based public outreach initiative and accompany this with outreach events across Oregon to build awareness of how chemistry research contributes to a healthy economy and societal well-being. Activities of the center in these areas as well as its
science initiatives will be monitored by an external advisory board and evaluation consultants.

The Center for Sustainable Materials Chemistry is funded as part of the Centers for Chemical Innovation (CCI) program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CSMC’s Grand Challenge is to create and study new chemistries that will enable technology solutions for a sustainable planet. Over the next 25 years, all global population growth is expected to be absorbed by cities. Electronics and clean-energy technologies must play increasing roles to make these burgeoning municipalities efficient, clean, and sustainable. Cloud services, countless mobile devices, clean-energy technologies, and medical, manufacturing, and transportation sensors must be made available on scales and at costs not yet realized. The unimagined benefits of artificial intelligence will be realized in a new era of smart machines. The CSMC has delivered new chemical building blocks and methods that will enable manufacturers to shape and enhance the performance of this complex technology web.

The CSMC

  • Integrated new analytical methods to identify and characterize new oxo-hydroxo metal clusters
  • Expanded the catalog of new oxo-hydroxo clusters and their reactions
  • Created new computational models to predict and assess speciation
  • Created new computational models for amophous oxide films
  • Integrated mulitple in-situ analytical methods to characterize the reaction paths of clusters to dense films
  • Developed priniciples to describe the conversion of clusters to dense films
  • Developed models and principles to describe EUV nanopatterning with oxo-hydroxo metal clusters
  • Transformed processing of solution-deposited oxide thin films
  • Transformed functionality of solution-processed thin-film oxide insulators and conductors
  • Transformed directed patterning with inorganic materials

The CSMC trained a diverse set of chemists by integrating innovation education, professional development, and research. Graduates have assumed leadership roles in industry, startups, and academe. CSMC research outcomes are being commercialized for semiconductor manufacturing and in devices for electronics and energy generation.


Last Modified: 08/29/2017
Modified by: Douglas A Keszler
